content: As I understand it, the difficulty of puzzles cannot be changed dynamically; otherwise, how can we explain that this puzzle remains hard, and [this](https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/dice-probability-calculator) one is medium?
I removed the constant-formatted N and changed N to "length of expression".

It’s not an equation since there is no equality symbol.
It’s an expression.
You seem to believe that  the unitary minus is the binary minus.
This has to be solved using trees right ?
No, it doesn't have to use trees. You can just use a stack.

Hi selenae,

Thanks for checking the solutions.

It seems like there was a slight bug in my program causing the operations to be calculated out of order in some cases.

I have fixed the error, updated the answers, and added a few more test cases that purposefully catch the cases where my solution failed.

Stashio

I don't believe I used the word equation anywhere, I only used "expression" as you said.

Unary negate is not one of the operators mentioned. If you look at one of the examples, you'll see that subtraction and negation are separate:

6--6/3, this is 6 minus -6 dividedby 3.

I replaced equation by expression.

The unary minus is not explained, is it before +?

Yeah, about unary minus, I gotta say it's unspecified *and* doesn't significantly add to the problem

I'd remove it if I were you.

Great problem otherwise!

Thanks for the feedback everyone.

@nicola
Are you saying that you suggest I use 'equation' instead of 'expression'? Looking up the definition of expression in mathematics, it gives an example of '2x3' as an expression, which goes along with the fact that I have used it correctly here. Sorry if I am misunderstanding.

@JBM
I suppose the reason I like the negation as part of the problem is that it adds one extra gotcha for those who plan to solve this by splitting the operators in reverse order. What I mean by that is, you could solve this by taking the expression and splitting by '*', then for each sub-element you can split by '-', then for each sub-element, split by '/', then split by '+', add each sub-element, divide each sub-element, etc. This type of solution leads to a rather ugly one-liner in languages like python, javascript, and ruby. Here's a working example for python (though it would not work for tests with negation):

print(reduce(operator.mul,[reduce(operator.sub,[reduce(operator.floordiv,[eval(exp3) for exp3 in exp2.split('/')]) for exp2 in exp.split('-')]) for exp in input().split('*')]))

I feel like this type of solution takes a bit of the magic away from the problem. I had this in mind when adding the tests for the problem, and I thought adding in a negation would be a good speed bump in the road for those trying a solution like this.

I'll remove it if you still think I should, but perhaps instead I could add something in the description to state that negate has the highest priority.

Let me know what you think, and thanks again for the feedback.

No, I replaced myself equation by expression.
You should just tell somewhere that unary minus is before +.

I don't like, but am fine with unary minus staying as long as it's acknowledged (and specified, priority-wise) in the statement.

Like, putting one in the example as a bare minimum.
Putting it in the example is a good idea. I have updated the problem description to acknowledge unary minus. It should be clear now that it has highest priority.
Edited to specify a few remaining constraints and approved.
